System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.

An A-module M is called a free A-module if it has a basis, i.e., a free system of generators. In this case, every element x in M admits a representation x = sum_{i in I} a_i x_i with coefficients a_i in A that are unique.
Does the concept of a/an System of Generators of an Ideal need to be defined for a definition of a/an Free A-module to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Free A-module involves the idea of a basis or a free system of generators for the module itself, which means that every element of the module can be uniquely expressed as a linear combination of these basis elements with coefficients from the ring A. This concept is focused on the structure of the module and its elements.

On the other hand, the concept of a System of Generators of an Ideal pertains specifically to the generation of ideals within a ring. It involves expressing an ideal as a sum of products of ring elements with elements from a generating set. This concept is specific to the structure of ideals within rings and does not directly relate to the structure of modules or their bases.

Therefore, understanding or defining a Free A-module does not require the concept of a System of Generators of an Ideal. The two concepts operate within different contexts: one in the realm of module theory and the other in ring and ideal theory. Thus, the definition of a Free A-module can be fully understood and applied without reference to how ideals are generated in a ring.
